skill.name: domain-profiles
skill.description: Domain-specific configuration profiles for learning resource creation. Defines search strategies, special fields, terminology policies, and content structures for different academic domains: technology, history, science, arts, and general. Use when researcher or writer agents need domain-adapted behavior.
skill.summary: Domain-specific configuration profiles for learning resource creation. Defines search strategies, sp...
skill.author: BitYoungjae

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing markdown guidelines for domain-adapted content creation. No executable code, no scripts, no network calls. Contains only Read, WebSearch, and WebFetch tool references which are appropriate for research documentation.

content.value_statement: Create adaptive educational content by configuring AI agents with domain-specific search strategies, terminology policies, and content structures. Supports technology, history, science, arts, and general topics.
actual_capabilities: Provides domain-adapted search strategies for technology, history, science, arts, and general topics
Defines terminology policies with bilingual glossaries (Korean/English)
Specifies content structures and document organization for each domain
Includes review criteria for quality assurance by AI reviewers
Standardizes persona.md sections with domain-specific guidelines
Maps search sources and quality indicators for each academic field
limitations: Does not generate content directly - provides configuration for other agents
Does not execute code or interact with external APIs
Requires integration with researcher/writer agents to produce output
Language focus is primarily Korean/English bilingual content

use_cases.title: Technology tutorials
use_cases.description: Create programming guides with code examples, version notes, and best practices for Korean learners

use_cases.title: Historical curricula
use_cases.description: Develop history lessons with primary source citations, timeline formats, and multi-perspective analysis

use_cases.title: STEM documentation
use_cases.description: Build science materials with LaTeX equations, lab safety notes, and problem sets

prompt_templates.title: Basic research setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Read skills/domain-profiles/technology.md and apply the search strategy to research {topic}. List authoritative sources and key concepts.

prompt_templates.title: History content structure
prompt_templates.prompt: Read skills/domain-profiles/history.md and design a content structure for {historical_event}. Include timeline format and perspective balance guidelines.

prompt_templates.title: Science equation formatting
prompt_templates.prompt: Read skills/domain-profiles/science.md and use the equation format guidelines to explain {scientific_concept}. Include LaTeX notation and bilingual terminology.

prompt_templates.title: Arts technique guides
prompt_templates.prompt: Read skills/domain-profiles/arts.md and structure a guide for {art_technique}. Include visual reference requirements and practice exercise format.

output_examples.input: Read skills/domain-profiles/technology.md and create a search strategy for learning Python async programming
output: Primary sources: Python official documentation, PEPs, Real Python tutorials
Search queries: 'Python async await tutorial', 'asyncio official guide', 'async best practices 2025'
Key concepts: coroutines, event loop, awaitable objects, task scheduling
Code policy: Type hints required, docstrings in Google style, error handling expected

best_practices: Load the appropriate domain profile before any research or writing tasks
Apply terminology policies consistently - Korean term followed by English in parentheses on first use
Use domain-specific content structures to match reader expectations
Follow review criteria to ensure quality before publishing
anti_patterns: Using general templates instead of domain-specific profiles
Skipping terminology glossaries for technical concepts
Ignoring version notes when documenting technology topics
Writing single-perspective content on controversial historical topics

faq.question: Which domain should I use for a topic?
faq.answer: Match the topic to its primary field: programming and APIs use technology, historical events use history, scientific concepts use science, creative disciplines use arts, and everything else uses general.

faq.question: How do I handle topics that span multiple domains?
faq.answer: Use the general/language profile for cross-domain topics. Include perspectives from each relevant domain with clear section headers.

faq.question: Can I customize these profiles for my needs?
faq.answer: Yes, the profiles are guidelines. Modify terminology policies, content structures, or add domain-specific fields to match your target audience.

faq.question: How does this integrate with other dokhak agents?
faq.answer: The researcher and writer agents read domain profiles before tasks. The reviewer agent uses review criteria from profiles to evaluate output quality.

faq.question: What tools can agents use with this skill?
faq.answer: Read for accessing profile files, WebSearch for finding sources, and WebFetch for retrieving web content. No file writing or code execution.

faq.question: How do I add a new domain profile?
faq.answer: Create a new markdown file in the domain-profiles directory with the same structure: search strategy, special fields, terminology policy, content structure, and review criteria.
